comments.text:
The problem with Fallout 3 was that it didn't run on quad-core processors. 
Using a quad-core with the game would cause it to speed up and act all 
janky. The .dll file that was released basically tricks the game into 
thinking that it runs on a dual core and fixes the problem. I'm not sure if 
that was patched in or not, but when I got the GOTY version a few years ago 
I had to download the .dll manually.

top_comment.text:
Point Lookout was a surreal, weird place, filled with inbred, mutated 
hilbillies, religious fanatics, 200-year old rivals, Chinese espionage and 
a pretty suspicious steamboat driver. The most surreal part was of course 
the part where you inhale the spores from the big fruit and you get these 
crazy hallucinations. It got really weird at the end, when I met this guy 
in a suit standing behind a nuclear bomb, like the one in Megaton. I 
thought it was Burke who had come back to haunt me! Then I woke up with a 
huge scar on my head, and later found out it wasn't even one from the 
Church who had lobotomized me, it was just the steamboat driver. And he 
kept the gray matter he'd torn out in jars, the creepy bastard! And those 
Punga worshippers "God" turned out to be a complete lie, It was just a 
hologram of a 200-year old man's brain.﻿

comments.author: Saul Cook

comments.text:
+eviljam13 Not looking to pick any fights here, just saying what I think.
The main things I, and probably a lot of other people dislike about 3:
-Lack of innovation - They recycled way too much stuff from the older games 
(BoS, Enclave, Super Mutants, Story begins from a vault, Deathclaws, 
Harold, even Dogmeat)
-Black and white morality - Pretty much every guest has a clear cut good 
and bad outcome, as well as every character is a straight up good or bad 
guy. Choices you make lack consequences and basically don't affect anything.
-Godlike character - Things like putting Intelligence to 9 when starting 
the game and going straight to Rivet City to get the Int Bobblehead, and 
perks like Almost Perfect completely destroy the core purpose of the 
SPECIAL system.
-Dialogue and writing - The dialogue is extremely immature and simplistic, 
when compared to the older games and New Vegas. The way you can convince 
Autumn and Eden to stand down sound like they were ripped off from a 
B-class Hollywood movie.
-Twisting the lore for the developer's own purposes - The Brotherhood was 
made good simply because Bethesda wanted to have someone as the "good 
guys". Same goes for the Enclave, which was included in the game simply to 
have someone as the "bad guys". The only real reason you're kicked out of 
your vault after the Trouble on the Home Front guest is that the developers 
could pull off a reference to Fallout 1.
There's more I could talk about but this comment has gotten pretty long.
comments.author: Villejh

top_comment.author: Radical Lad

comments.text:
+Radical Lad "Isn't even Enclave" is an odd way to see it... so I'll say 
both yes and no. Yes because they appear to be remnants of pre-war US gov't 
as well, but no because they're... different.

"(Then who was phone?)"
Sorry I don't know what you're trying to ask. I can't answer that.

Here is some text from the terminal In Grayditch that I found on the 
fallout wiki proving what I said:

"I can't believe I went through all that trouble to leave Navarro and make 
my way across the country just to get stuck in this shithole. I'll be 
damned if I'm going to die here.
Now that we're cut off from Lesko and Wilks, I think we're on our own. The 
damn ants keep trying to find a way to get inside the house. Even as I'm 
typing this, I can hear them scraping the walls looking for a way through. 
I don't know how much longer we can last."

We can see that he is, in fact, an Enclave soldier from Navarro. He seems 
to have escaped and traveled across the country. He couldn't bring much 
gear with him, I guess.

"I was scavenging some of the near buildings for junk to sell and came 
across a working radio. No sooner did I turn it on than I heard the 
familiar patriotic anthems they used to play whenever Richardson would give 
a speech. But this was different. Who the hell is President Eden? When did 
that happen? Are they on this coast too? Most importantly, will they come 
looking for me?
I hope this journey wasn't a huge mistake."

So this guy, from the Western Enclave, has never heard of Eden, who is 
allegedly the president of the Enclave (as the Eastern Enclave would say). 
He doesn't even know how they got here, or when. They're just there and 
it's weird as hell. They aren't looking for him because Enclave never set 
foot in that town. They aren't looking for him because they don't know that 
he ran away, or even the fact that he is an ex-Enclave soldier, so that 
shows that Eastern Enclave don't even know that a Western counterpart 
exists, and vice-versa.
comments.author: nkorea

comments.text:
+nkorea So the East Coast Enclave isn't even Enclave?
(Then who was phone?)
comments.author: Radical Lad

comments.text:
+Radical Lad I suppose you do make a point with the whole Enclave 
disbandment/travel theory, one thing to always consider is that the two 
Enclaves (East and West) allegedly don't even know of each other. This can 
be seen in one of the houses in Grayditch (the town in F3 overrun by fire 
ants). Basically the resident of that house worked with the western 
Enclave, and the Enclave in the east apparently had no idea. As for the 
whole BoS thing, again, a majority of Lyons' BoS aren't from the west, and 
therefore don't follow the Codex. Also, Lyons' BoS went to the Pitt, not 
the "traditional" one, explaining why they didn't "kill everyone there". 
Yes, the Codex is pretty much a religion of brainwashing but that doesn't 
mean there can't be any people who betray it like Lyons' did, obviously 
noted that the Outcasts actually call Lyons a traitor. As for the BoS being 
"cold-blooded motherfuckers", that description matches the Outcasts who 
both follow the Codex AND treat the player and locals like shit (eg. 
attempting to kill you right after unlocking the door in Op Anchorage).


Sorry for the vague details pertaining to the dead Western Enclave guy in 
Grayditch. I haven't played F3 in years... so I don't remember much detail. 
If you can, play it again and search one of the shacks and read the 
terminal entries. You'll see what I mean.
comments.author: nkorea

comments.text:
+nkorea
Here are some things I dug up that I didn't even know about
 - The oil rig is the main base of operations for the Enclave.

- The only other "base" worth mentioning is Navarro, which is new and 
understaffed.

- Navarro is nothing but a vertibird fueling station at this point in time.

- If the oil rig were to be destroyed, the Enclave would be decimated 
(according to their top scientist).

- Vertibirds can't fly long distances without refueling (they ARE just 
helicoptors)

- The Enclave, while technically the remnants of the US government, are 
little more than overzealous bigots with big guns. They sell slaves/drugs, 
and their goal is to restore humanity to its former glory by killing off 
pretty much everything in the wastelands.

They have no reason to be on the East coast. And yes. IN GAME you can learn 
all this, and that the Enclave's only bases are the Oil Rig, and an 
understaffed Navarro.

And once again with the BoS. You can't just suddenly change your heart 
after being raised by a codex which is pretty much their religion. And I'm 
not talking about casual christians. I mean a religion that can be similar 
to brainwashing. The Elder Lyons and his group should have just stayed in 
the Pentagon and sung songs about Liberty Prime. If they had gone to the 
pitt then they probably would have killed everyone there. The BoS are a 
bunch of cold blooded mother fuckers.

comments.text:
+Radical Lad Okay, when you say is your opinion. I have no problem with it. 
But when you jackasses go and say (I wish Fallout 3 was non-canon) then 
shit hits the fan. The reason they brought Ghouls to the East is to make 
Fallout familiar. I a sure you wackos would be saying Fallout was not 
fallout if there were no BoS, no Enclave, no Ghouls and if the 
Super-Mutants were different. But let me give you a little bit of lesson my 
friend:

The reason the Vault 87 are similar to the Mater's, is because is the same 
FEV with slight alterations. It is explained in the different terminals and 
holotapes you guys seem to ignore, plus Fawkes explains a little bit more.

The reason the BoS turned into a faction of goody-two-shoes is well 
explained in man conversations with different BoS soldiers, Scribes and 
Outcast alike. Then there's the Outcast which are the true BoS, and feel 
like the true BoS sending you to impossible suicide missions, like the West 
Coast BoS do. Lyons reached Elder because he was one of the best, and he 
earned that title when discovering Liberty Prime. It is explained by 
Casdin, Rothchild, Bowditch, Peabody and many more, how he was one of the 
most skilled and toughest of Paladins (shows mow much you pay attention to 
the game u close-minded fool). There are two main reasons he went soft. 
Firsty, he became a father. Secondly, he got old, and seeing how the 
Super-mutant threat (which was one of their main missions) was killing many 
innocent lives, he decided to act. Many of the scribes are pissed at Lyons, 
but serve with him non-the-less. And the true BoS, when finding out Lyons 
turned 'native' they ceased communications with them, since Lyons had tried 
to convince them to bring back up.

The Ghouls, yes that is a convenience, but a welcomed one.

The Enclave, the only thing I am pissed is that we have the option to help 
hem, but they still attack you. It is also well explained why there were 
many Enclave troops. And guess what? There's bound to be more. The Enclave 
remnants might be hundreds of them. Few o what it was before, but come on, 
they are the United States FEDERAL government.

If anything, all you original Fallout fans do is bitch and whine 
annoyingly like the Batman-fans do when Batman gets defeated by a foe. It 
makes me sick!

EDIT: There is one thing we can agree on, and that is the fact that some 
people are 'essential' and can't die, until we finish a quest. Why? Because 
the story is a little linear. But it does NOT ruins the fun and definitely 
does NOT ruin the lore.
comments.author: Mad Max Rockatansky

comments.text:
+Mad Max Rockatansky Listen, it's your opinion on how spectacular Oblivions 
with guns' lore was, I personally think it was shit. There was one too many 
"coincidences" in it. Like how F3 super mutants were "coincidentally" just 
like the West ones. And how the Enclave "coincidentally" had enough 
troopers away from Navarro and the oil rig to make a full force military. 
And how the BoS "coincidentally" has a soft hearted leader (which I wonder 
how he managed to be elder in the first place).
I was saying that *IMO* (a term you guys can't seem to grasp) if anything 
Fo3 is the odd one out, because it takes place in the East coast (small 
detail, but worth noting), and the atmosphere was just a zombie game, but 
instead of zombies, it had scorpions, rats, and ghouls (speaking of ghouls, 
in the first 2 games, it wasn't just Radiation that made them, it was about 
200 worth years of radiation leaking through a crack in the door, along 
side some sort of industrial chemical which I can't name for the life of 
me. The ghouls in Necropolis really should be the only ghouls, now back to 
my statement), and instead of finding a cure, you had to filter some water 
(that was still irradiated after 200 years). The game also has one of the 
most bullshit frustrating mechanics ever, that certain characters are 
invincible unless you do a quest for them. *IF I WANTED TO KILL THEM WHY 
WOULD I DO A QUEST FOR THEM*

captions.text:
Would YOU like to improve this series and
help keep it alive? Of course you would! Zip

on by our Patreon page and see how you can
do just that and so much more. Act now, and

unlock exclusive content, including bonus
lore audio books and other fabulous prizes.

What are you waiting for? Be a hero! Visit
us today.

When the Great War destroyed civilization,
humanity's petty rivalries died along with

the people who harbored them. From the leaders
of nations right down to neighbors squabbling

over their gardens, the voices went silent
when the bombs fell. But there are is a small

group of people who survived the war and kept
on living for hundreds of years afterwards.

Along with their deformed bodies and deteriorating
minds, they've also kept alive their grievances

from hundreds of years ago. They call themselves
a microcosm of the old world, and they play

an endless game of treachery and manipulation
that has lasted so long they can barely remember
why they're fighting.

The old world was filled with secretive people
and organizations. Small towns and seemingly

innocent locations could hold both wonders
and horrors. Beneath those wholesome diversions

were many secrets, some of which simply refused
to die. Point Lookout National Park was a

ways south of Washington DC, far enough to
not get scorched by the bombardment during

the war, but it still got a good dose of fallout
pouring in through the waters of the Potomac.

There are some records of what it was like
in the final days, left behind by a medical

team that passed through.
The backwater residents of the place were

hit hard by the New Plague that spread across
the land in the years before the war. The

government had sent in a series of medical
experts to curb the spread of the plague,

but the locals weren't exactly hospitable
to outsiders. And that was back before they'd
had two centuries of inbreeding and mutation.

Now the place is crawling with a local flavor
of mutant hillbillies who survive off a regional

fruit called the punga. They supplement their
diet with whatever protein they can find,

and that usually comes from travelers who
visit Point Lookout searching for pre-war
loot.
"Come out and play!"
"Come on out."
"We ain't gunno bite."
"I hear something moving!"
"Don't you go runnin'!"
"I'm gunno eat good tonight!"
"You in the wrong place girl!"
"Oh my god! Someone help me!"
"I got somethin' for ya!"
No! No! Please! Get away!
"You ain't got no chance!"

The only way to reach the peninsula is by boat,
and on the Potomac there used to be a man

with an antique paddle steamer. Claimed that
he once sailed up the Atlantic coast all the
way up to the Commonwealth.

He would sell punga fruit to traders in Washington
– although he never seemed to bring any

goods with him back to Point Lookout, aside
from passengers. Those passengers usually

didn't return to their point of origin but,
according to the few that have, there is a

church down in Point Lookout that is surprisingly
welcoming to newcomers.

The church was the Ark and Dove, named after
the ships that brought the first settlers

to Maryland close to eight hundred years ago.
The Calvert family was among the first people

to settle the region, and by the time of the
Great War, they had influence in politics,

finance, and industry. They could pull strings
with General Atomics, and had the clout to

acquire and scientific acumen to modify the
military biogel that keeps disembodied brains alive.

They had the kind of resources to keep a person
alive through the apocalypse, and beyond.

That kind of influence also brings enemies.
One explorer came back from Point Lookout

full of stories of pre-War rivalries that
bubbled up again like swamp gas. A ghoul had

been stalking the Calverts for over two hundred
years, and the knowledge that one of them

might still be alive drew him back to the
Calvert ancestral estate in Point Lookout.

Desmond Lockheart has been an international
operative since the Resource Wars of the twenty

first century. Now, that man's on the radar
of every organization from the Regulators

to Talon Company, to Littlehorn & Associates.
Not many ghouls in the wasteland have a British

accent, so that “bloke” stands out wherever
he goes. Doesn't make him any less conspicuous

that he always travels with a pair of tough
as nails attack dogs, and carries enough ordnance
to blow up a Brotherhood bunker.

I was never sure how his rivalry with Calvert
turned out. Desmond isn't the sort to linger

around swapping stories of his exploits, but
one or both of them must be dead, for sure.

But that feud was only one of the hidden horrors
of Point Lookout. The locals called it haunted

long before things like ghouls ever existed,
and that swamp has deep roots that dig down

to what a praying man would call hell. But
that is a story for another day...
